column6: Variable name
column7: Intuitive description
column8: Technical description
column10: Sources

column6: Personal housing assets. Average All Ages. individuals
column7: Average Personal housing assets within a given percentile group. Personal housing assets are dwellings (including land underlying dwellings) held by households.. The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals of all ages. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Personal housing assets]=[Personal dwellings]+[Personal land underlying dwellings]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz & Pierre Brassac (2020).[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Personal debt. Average All Ages. individuals
column7: Average Personal debt within a given percentile group. Personal debt is debts or legal obligations owned by the personal sector (households).. The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals of all ages. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz & Pierre Brassac (2020).[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Private housing assets. Average All Ages. individuals
column7: Average Private housing assets within a given percentile group. Private housing assets are dwellings (including land underlying dwellings) held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth. The population is comprised of individuals of all ages. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Private housing assets]=[Private dwellings]+[Private land underlying dwellings]

Series updated by Luis Bauluz & Pierre Brassac (2020).[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column9: 1987-1995: based on the evolution of the tax value of single-family homes + agricultural properties (i.e., the 2 main categories of households' real estate). Before 1987: based on evolution of Olesen 2009 series. We checked that this gives results consistent with house price indices: housing slump from 1979 to 1982; then boom from 1982 to 1986; then slump from 1986 to 1995; then gradual increase through to 2004; then huge boom from mid-2004 to mid-2006 then slump.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Private housing assets are dwellings (including land underlying dwellings) held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth. The population is comprised of individuals of all ages. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Private housing assets]=[Private dwellings]+[Private land underlying dwellings]
